node.title: adaptive mesh refinement and block generation
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello everyone,
Recently, I found a paper dealing with the additive manufacturing process simulation with adaptive mesh refinement implemented via DEAL.II. The key adaptive mesh refinement concept in that paper is to use a coarse mesh for the initial set up and then refine/coarsen the mesh as needed to reduce computational cost. As shown in the following picture, 1) the top-most active layer contains 1 element in the build direction; 2) elements near the top surface are refined; 3) elements far away from the top surface are coarsen; 4) elements near the part boundaries are refined. I want to implement this concept with MOOSE. However, I got some problems.
Suppose a block of size 4e-3 x 4e-3 x 4e-3 is initially meshed with 5x5x5 elements. The layer thickness is 50e-6, so that 4 refinement levels are needed to reach such a cell size. The top surface moves every second as defined by CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier  and an AuxVariable. An error message is displayed: "The block '1' has not been found in the network" when I run the code. I know that if I use 80 (4e-3 / 50e-6 = 80) elements, the code can run. However, the initial mesh in such a case is already a fine mesh and I can't coarsen the mesh to a larger size. How can I get the mesh to look like the picture?

[Problem]
  kernel_coverage_check = false
  boundary_restricted_node_integrity_check = false
  boundary_restricted_elem_integrity_check = false
  type = FEProblem
[]

[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    nx = 5
    ny = 5
    nz = 5
    xmax = 4e-3
    ymax = 4e-3
    zmax = 4e-3
  []
  [active_domain] #the initially active domain
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = 'gen'
    block_id = 1
    bottom_left = '0 0 0'
    top_right = '4e-3 4e-3 50e-6'
  []
  [inactive_domain] #the initially inactive domain
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = active_domain
    block_id = 2
    bottom_left = '0 0 50e-6'
    top_right = '4e-3 4e-3 4e-3'
  []
  [sideset_top]
    input = inactive_domain
    type = SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator
    normal = '0 0 1'
    block = 1
    new_boundary = 'sideset_top' # top boundary of active domain
  []
[]

[Variables]
  [T]
    initial_condition = 300 #Kelvin
    block = 1
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [layerZ]
    [AuxKernel]
      type = ParsedAux
      expression = 'z - 50e-6 * ceil(t/1.000001)'
      use_xyzt = true
      execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
    []
  []
[] 

[Kernels]
  [conduction]
    block = 1
    type = ADHeatConduction
    variable = T
  []
[]

[MeshModifiers]
  [addLayer] 
    type = CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier
    coupled_var = 'layerZ'
    criterion_type = BELOW
    threshold = 0
    subdomain_id = 1
    moving_boundaries = 'sideset_top'
    moving_boundary_subdomain_pairs = '1 2'
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [thermal]
    block = 1
    type = ADHeatConductionMaterial
    specific_heat = 1
    thermal_conductivity = 1e-3
  []
  [density]
    block = 1
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = '1'
  []
  [dummy_mat_inactive]
    block = 2
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'dummy_mat'
    prop_values = '0.0'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  # In 3D, back = 0, bottom = 1, right = 2, top = 3, left = 4, front = 5
  [bottom]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    variable = T
    boundary = 0
    value = 400
  []
  [side_top_BC]
    type = ADConvectiveHeatFluxBC
    T_infinity = 500
    heat_transfer_coefficient = 100
    variable = T
    boundary = sideset_top
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = PJFNK
  petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart -pc_type -pc_hypre_type -pc_hypre_boomeramg_max_iter'
  petsc_options_value = '201                hypre    boomeramg      8'
  end_time = 80
  dt = 0.1
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-10
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-12
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

Does your starting mesh show block 1 as expected?
Which object is returning the error? It should say in the console
This combination of adaptivity criteria should be easy to do in moose. We can combine Markers to target each of these needs

The simulation didn't run, it failed to pass the check. I got an error message The block '1' was not found in the mesh. I think the reason for this is that when the initial mesh is set as 5x5x5 for a cubic with length of 4e-3, then 4e-3 / 5 = 800e-6, the top right to create the block should be
top_right = '4e-3 4e-3 800e-6'
rather than
top_right = '4e-3 4e-3 50e-6'
And also for the block 2, the bottom left should be
bottom_left = '0 0 800e-6'
I will try it tomorrow.

I simplified the input file to a 2D case, and here is the initial mesh generated within below input file. However, the active and inactive domains and the moving boundary are not as expected as shown in the picture. Also, the moving boundary moves in an incorrect way. I would like the moving boundary to move along the Y-direction 50e-6 every second.

What should I do to make the active and inactive domains and the moving boundary change correctly?
Which marker is suitable for refining or coarsening the mesh near a boundary? Here I want to refine the mesh near the moving boundary and coarsen the mesh far from the moving boundary.

    # [box]

What should I do to make the active and inactive domains and the moving boundary change correctly?

For moving subdomains and boundaries, you can use this object
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshmodifiers/CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier.html
then for example, using a FunctionAux for example to make an auxiliary variable describe the subdomain changes to make happen

Which marker is suitable for refining or coarsening the mesh near a boundary? Here I want to refine the mesh near the moving boundary and coarsen the mesh far from the moving boundary.

This one
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/markers/BoundaryMarker.html

What part is not working as you expect? The boundary movement or the refinement?
I think the coarsening once the boundary has moved wont be automatic. Or if it is, it will have to be handled by a separate Marker not by the boundary marker

Thanks a lot. Both the boundary movement and refinement do not work as expected. Sometimes they both work correctly, but sometimes they do not. Also, I can't understand why so many boundaries are generated.

I think the coarsening once the boundary has moved wont be automatic. Or if it is, it will have to be handled by a separate Marker not by the boundary marker

Correct. I need additional markers to coarsen the mesh far away from the moving boundary.
Below picture shows some results based on the above input file.

Both the boundary movement

It's on a per element basis, and the criteria is a comparison to 0 which is a value that the criteria hits exactly. So that's why you see dents like at 26.1

ceil(t/1.000001)

is not a great idea in the expression. This means that sometimes you get two (or more) steps that have the same value for ceil
so then the criteria does not move even though the time changed

Also, I can't understand why so many boundaries are generated.

this seems to be a bug with adaptivity. The boundary is not traveling as expected, it's being created multiple times.
I dont think libMesh can delete sides using the refined elements at this point.
I ll see if we can do something in MOOSE

Nothing obvious comes to mind.
@dschwen are you planning on adding support for mesh adaptivity to the SidesetsAroundSubdomainsUpdater by any chance?

is not a great idea in the expression. This means that sometimes you get two (or more) steps that have the same value for ceil
so then the criteria does not move even though the time changed

I tried using ceil(t) to replace ceil(t/1.000001), however, we got the same results, even for the result at t=26.1.

I dont think libMesh can delete sides using the refined elements at this point.
I ll see if we can do something in MOOSE

Thanks and looking forward any improvement.

The top elements in the yellow domain are at level 4, not level 5, even though I set the moving boundary as the boundary maker. I want these elements to be at the same level as the finest.

This might not be tied to updating the sideset. it could be:

the adaptivity step is not run after a sideset update but after. This would mean we refine the old version of the boundary, then move the boundary. You can use Debug/show_execution_order to see how the user objects are executed. Adaptivty should have some verbosity so you can compare the ordering of the two
the adaptivity set up is such that the most refined version is not at the sideset. This would be the complex interaction of the the two markers. It's unlikely but then again you really have to check the error indicator to predict how that ErrorFractionMarker behaves

I set execution_order_group = -1 in  both the addLayer and the side_updater section, and show_execution_order = 'ALWAYS TIMESTEP_BEGIN'.
Below shows the debug output. We can see the addLayer executed first and the side_updater second, then the boundary_marker, error_frac and combo executed after the calculation of each step. In this case, even though the simulation moves to the next step (e.g. from step 1 to step 2), the boundary in the makers is still the old version one, so that we will see the mesh refinement is always one step later for these top most elements. A tricky setting might be to develop a Custom Timestepper and add a small time step before each current step. Do you have any suggestions?

I think we want side-updater to run after add-layer. We need the subdomains to be updated (by addLayer) then we can re-define the boundary between the two subdomains.
For that you can use the execution_order_group parameter that user objects have.

I think we want side-updater to run after add-layer. We need the subdomains to be updated (by addLayer) then we can re-define the boundary between the two subdomains.

Yes. I already set the execution_order_group = -1 for both the addLayer and side_updater, the results seem to be the same as previous.
Beside the current issues, I have another question: As shown in the figure below, the moving boundary contains 3 segments. We set the whole moving boundary as one marker in our input file, so that elements near this moving boundary are refined to max_h_level, resulting in a huge number of elements. But actually, for regions near these two orange lines, we hope that the elements could be as coarse as possible.
Is it possible to keep the moving boundary the same, but make the elements near the orange segments coarser? If the mesh is coarsened then the moving boundary could be changed and another issue is how to ensure that the moving boundary moves correctly to the next layer when the mesh size is greater than the layer thickness.

node.title: Problems when configuring MOOSE using PETSC with kokkos support
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
I learned through the PETSC official website that PETSC supports kokkos, after I successfully configured PETSC, I wanted to integrate this version of PETSC into MOOSE, but now there are some problems in the final run_test stage. I hope to get some advice and help

looks like you need two of these ComputePlaneSmallStrain.
Does it make sense to have one for each phase?
Either that, or you need to change the stress materials to stop requesting these strain quantities on a per-phase basis, but rather request some. sort of combined strain quantity for both phases

I do not think I need two of the computPlaneSmallStrain. So the main issue I am trying to solve is I have a 2D domain using ComputeCrystalPlasticityThermalEigenstrain with other related classes for eigen contribution but there is some stress-strain contribution from the z direction which I want to get rid of for now. That's why I am looking into the plane stress/strain classes. Is there a way to eliminate the contribution from the z direction or would I have to modify the class(ComputeCrystalPlasticityThermalEigenstrain) and eliminate the thermal coefficient expansion contribution in the z direction?

Is there a way to eliminate the contribution from the z direction

@sapitts @hchen139 has the computePlaneSmallStrain been used in combination with crystal plasticity models? Is there an example you know of?

I would not use crystal plasticity with computePlaneSmallStrain. Crystal plasticity is fundamentally a plastic deformation model, and a small total strain is not a good match for plastic deformation: computeFiniteStrain is better.
While I have seen  literature applying crystal plasticity in 2D, our models are not written for 2D use: the constitutive models assume a set of slip planes and slip directions in 3D space
@sapitts is there a way I can restrict or make the eigenstrain in a specific(say feig_zz) direction zero?

You could set the coefficient of the thermal expansion eigenstrain in the corresponding direction to zero, e.g. for zeroing out the zz eigenstrain, make the following change in the eigenstrain_0 block:
thermal_expansion_coefficients = '12.8e-06 12.8e-06 0.0'

@sapitts Yes I tried making the thermal expansion eigenstrain in the z direction zero but that did not work as the solution never converged. Even reducing the order of magnitude in the z direction had similar convergence issues. for example:
thermal_expansion_coefficients = '12.8e-06 12.8e-06 12.8e-15 '

node.title: Really slow convergence with my simulation
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A Navier Stokes is the most appropriate category for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (avoid screenshots if possible, triple back quotes before/after pasted text, etc)

Question
Hello,
I'm trying to run natural convection flow through a fuel bundle flow channel, but whenever I start the simulation it either converges at the timestep, around 0 seconds, or it doesn't converge when it increases the 'dt.' It just stays around the initial timestep. I'm not sure what's causing this or how to solve it. Could it be my mesh quality?

flow_across_bundle.txt

Mesh size and type: 5000, hex

Hello
you'll want to start with a simpler system / simpler mesh.
The mesh looks very coarse, but refining it wont let you troubleshoot the issue
Guillaume

Thanks!

node.title: EM module : test dipole
node.bodyText: Hi, I tested the dipole example. I checked it works well. I'd like to know how to normalize an electric field. Raw data does not show the perfect wave phase patterns.
@cticenhour

Thanks for your question @HyungseonSong-plasma. The test result uses a very coarse mesh in order to speed-up the simulation time, so the waveform is quite distorted using the test mesh. The mesh you should use here is described in the documentation: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/electromagnetics/benchmarks/DipoleAntenna.html
Here, I mention that you should generate the mesh using the Gmsh tool and the .geo file included in the test directory of the dipole antenna example. Using that file, you can navigate to the folder and then call Gmsh on the command line to generate the mesh quickly:
gmsh -2 dipole_antenna_1G.geo -clscale 0.2 -order 2 -algo del2d

You should have a .msh file as the output that you can then use in the input file (within the Mesh block) to run the case again at higher resolution.
Regarding normalization: in the data presented in the example, I am using a rather rudimentary boundary condition to excite the antenna. Therefore I couldn't, at the time that I made the example, guarantee the particular value of the electric field, but could guarantee the general waveform. Presenting the data in normalized form made more sense. What I mean by this is, performing the following calculation:
$$E_{\text{normalized}}(x, y) = \frac{E(x,y)}{\left|E_{\text{maximum}}\right|}$$
Hopefully this all makes sense. Feel free to ask more questions if you have them!
Thank you

node.title: Transferred variable in sub-app has the wrong value in material system
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone
I have a trouble in transfer variables in multiapps.
I am implementing a MultiAPP in Moose. And in the main app I calculate the elastic energy as material property. Then I save it as a AuxVariable using the following codes.
[AuxVariables]
  [elastic _energy]
   order = CONSTANT
   family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]
[AuxKernels]
[./positive_energy]
   type = MaterialRealAux
   variable = elastic_energy
   property = elastic _energy
 []
[]

After that I use Transfers system.
[Transfers]
  [to_positive_energy]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    to_multi_app = subapp
    variable = elastic_energy
    source_variable = elastic_energy
  []
[]


Then in subapp I have the code:
[AuxVariables]
  [elastic _energy]
   order = CONSTANT
   family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

And the I use elastic_energy in Material system in subapp, like this:
  [elastic_energy_from_mian_app]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = ' degradation'
    property_name = elastic_energy_in_material_system
    coupled_variables = 'elastic_energy'
    expression = 'elastic_energy'
    outputs = exodus
  []

Finally, I compare visualize the calculated results in Paraview. But the elastic energy in AuxVariables system and the elastic energy in Material system have the different values, like these:

Elastic energy in auxvaribales system

Elastic energy in Material system.
Why do they have different values? Is it something wrong in my codes?

Hello
We do expect a projection error from going from:

material property at each qp (which can be any shape!)
auxiliary variable (which is limited by its finite element order and family)

however not this big. These parameters dont make sense
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = ' degradation'
    property_name = elastic_energy_in_material_system

the material property names is for the arguments in the expression.
then you should make sure you are outputting on the same time step and not some initialization value. I m not sure what else could explain this

Hi GiudGiud
I delete  material_property_names = ' degradation'.  I would like to know if MOOSE's material system automatically updates the values at the beginning of each time step. Since I haven't made any additional settings for the timing of the output data, theoretically, these two elastic energy should have the same value.

I have uploaded my code, please see https://github.com/Yaode-Yin/MOOSE_2025-1-11/blob/main/fracture.i. In this subapp, I can safely obtain positive_energy from the main app and read it as an AuxVariable. However, when I call it within the material system, there is a noticeable difference in the value.
  [Free_energy_1]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
 #   material_property_names = ' degradation'
    property_name = F_1
    coupled_variables = 'positive_energy'
    expression = 'positive_energy'
    outputs = exodus
  []

I would like to know if MOOSE's material system automatically updates the values at the beginning of each time step

material properties are re-computed on each element when requested. So yes in effect they are automatically updated.
I'll take a look at the input soon
Thank you very much, Giud.  This seems to a bug in my code. The transferred variable cannot get its correct value in material system.  I still cannot fix it.

on the one input you uploaded, I get a good match between F_1 and postive energy, when setting the latter with an initial condition.
I might need the parent application input to reproduce the problem.
I have a feeling it is going to be tied to the execution ordering  between Transfers and the material property output (set to execute on the end of a time step)

I'm sorry for my current out of office. I'll upload my parent app later.
I can transfer the positive energy in main app to sub app safely, as shown in the first picture. But when I call positive energy as material property in sub app, I cannot get the correct value, as shown in the second picture.
Now I have no directions to fix my problem.

But when I call positive energy as material property in sub app, I cannot get the correct value, as shown in the second picture.

Yes but it's not what I am seeing in that subapp on its own

Hi, Giud. I find the problem in my input file. There is a mistake in the end_time in sub-app.
 start_time = 0.0   end_time = 5000e-9  dt = 1e-4 dtmin= 1e-4
The setted end time is too short.

node.title: Recovery computation problem
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello, I have encountered a problem. I used peacock to run the input file before, and specified the working folder as datas/nh/07/ in peacock (I can recover the calculation by using the Recover button in peacock, and I also set checkpoint in the input file).
Now I am going to execute the calculation from the command line and resume the calculation, using the following command, but there is an error, looking forward to your guidance.
mpiexec -n 72 ./combined-opt -i yz.i --output datas/nh/07/ --recover

Hello
You'll want to specify the name of the folder (with maybe also the beginning of the checkpoint file name) holding the checkpoint file since it is not finding it by itself
  --recover <optional file base>    Continue the calculation. Without <file base>, the most recent recovery file will be used
There are the following two folders in my work folder, which one is the required folder?
the one with _cp at the end
Thanks for the help, but the following error occurred

It's finding the right folder, it's just not trying to load the mesh in a distributed manner.
Try --distributed-mesh on the command line to make it load the /72/ folder

Thank you for your help. I have one more question, if I want the output to be in the folder（table2_1_01） I specified, am I using this command correctly?
mpiexec -n 72 ./combined-opt -i yz_sh_yqz_table2_1_01.i Outputs/csv=true --output sintering_datas/sh/table2_1_01

Ive never used --output.
Instead I specify Outputs/file_base= in the input file.
The folder can be part of the file_base

Thank you for your help. I am using this method now. However, my output doesn't have a name (see figure).
mpiexec -n 72 ./combined-opt -i yz_sh_yqz_table2_1_01.i Outputs/file_base='./sintering_datas/sh/table2_1_01/'

In addition, one of the nice things when running peacock is that after I execute it, the program will automatically generate a file of my input in the destination folder, how can I do this？
By the way, how do I turn off this part of the post-processor output from the command line? (I want to just not output on the command line, but not affect my output csv file)

The file base is not just the folder name, it s also the beginning of the name of the file.
This is why you have those ".e" files with no names
Thanks for your reply. How should I solve the remaining two problems

In addition, one of the nice things when running peacock is that after I execute it, the program will automatically generate a file of my input in the destination folder, how can I do this？

You mean a copy of the input? I dont know about that

By the way, how do I turn off this part of the post-processor output from the command line?

You can create a Console block and set 'hide/show' with the names of the postprocessors you want to show / hide
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/outputs/Console.html
There are also a number of options you can set directly in the Outputs block that apply to all outputs
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/CommonOutputAction.html

node.title: how to  improve the efficiency of HPC process?
node.bodyText:
I am trying to use MPI functionality for large-scale parallel computing on a supercomputer cluster. The number of solving units is in the tens of millions, and the number of degrees of freedom of nodes is in the billions.
When I was solving a problem with millions of degrees of freedom, I found that the solving efficiency was already very slow. The official suggested a single core degree of freedom of 20000, but currently my single core solving degree of freedom is only about 10000.
What aspects should I improve the calculation settings to significantly increase computational efficiency and meet the demand for solving billions of degrees of freedom?

Hello
This is a complex problem and the simplest step to take is simply to profile a shorter run to see which step in your simulation is not scaling to tens of millions of cores. The limiting step is likely specific to your problem and to your solver setup.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/profiling.html

Hello

For the groundwater i use the Water97FluidProperties and for the gas phase i planed to use the NitrogenFluidProperties but then the code takes forever to compute the residual, so i use the IdealGasFluidProperties. In hopes to simplify my code and better the convergence i also used the SimpleFluidProperties but they gave worse convergence than the Water97Properties. I also reduced my timestep in order to improve convergence but that didn't have a great impact.

This is good feedback. I think these other properties have been implemented for correctness rather than performance. The trick here to speed it up is either do what you did, or use a TabulatedFluidProperties. This can be used to generate a tabulation (using a different fp object) then load the tabulation and only use that (no need to specify fp anymore)
With regards to convergence issues, this page should help:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html
notably it would be good to know (on a small mesh) if the problem is well posed and does have any singular value

Hey @julianseb - have you managed to get a simpler model working (so maybe one with constant temperature or even single phase flow or even a mesh without a hole)? I always find it easiest to get something simple working and then build on that.
I can't see anything that is jumping out with your input file that is obviously wrong.
Also, interesting that the convergence is worse with Ideal gas and simple fluid properties, as they definitely have the correct derivatives! So it must be something else

I think I have found your main problem. You have
[mass_frac_boden]
  type = PorousFlowMassFraction
  PorousFlowDictator = dictator_boden
  block = 'boden'
  mass_fraction_vars = 'pp gp'
[]

The mass_fraction_vars parameter expects the mass fraction of species 1 in fluid phase 0 etc, but you are giving it the pressure variables. These are not in the range [0,1] so it is struggling to solve.
I think that is you have two fluid phases with a single fluid component in each (so only water in liquid phase, only gas in the gas phase) that you can just use mass_fraction_vars = '1 0' (so mass fraction of water in liquid is 1, mass fraction of water in gas is 0, and the others are computed from them).

I agree with @lynnmunday that it doesn't look big enough to run out of memory.
You could try a different preconditioned option instead of mumps. Another common one used for porous flow is
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -sub_pc_type -sub_pc_factor_shift_type'
petsc_options_value = ' asm      lu           NONZERO'

One more thing - your PorousFlowOutflowBC might work better if you specify the parameter
mass_fraction_component = 1

so it doesn't try and remove non-existant water in the gas phase.

Is that for the really simple square mesh? It might have reached a steady state and can't solve any further? Do the results look like what you expect? Does the mesh with a circle work with those changes?

Yes, thats for the simple uniform mesh.
I would say it looks like expected. The artifacts are probably because of the coarse grid. And the temperature increase could be handled by a OutflowBC.


For the complex grid with the circle it shows a simmilar behaviour. For the first time steps it is running fine and at some point ist starts stagnating. It just shows a corious behaviour for the gas pressure:

And following on that also for the saturations of the two phases.


Would you say it would be the easiest to just adapt the IC and BC for the gaspressure? I would have thougt that the line of saturation change would be higher, closer to where i set the pp with the gradient. So going from 10 on the left to 8 on the right.
But otherwise i would say the convergence issues are handeld. Thank you !!!

@cpgr is an expert in this so definitely follow all of his suggestions before trying mine.
Anyway, I think you can get rid of temperature as a variable by creating a PorousFlowTemperature material called temperature:
[Materials]
  [temperature]
    type = PorousFlowTemperature
    temperature = T
  []
[]

You can initialize temperature with this:
[AuxVariables]
  [T]
    initial_condition = 293
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

This should then work with [FluidProperties] type = TabulatedBicubicFluidProperties
I think your smaller mesh should work.  With a small mesh you can output the jacobian and see if it looks bad:
petsc_options = '-pc_svd_monitor'
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
petsc_options_value = 'svd'

Tabulated fluid properties will definitely make it faster when using Nitrogen as the gas as it avoids the iterative step to compute pressure - good call @lynnmunday
It looks like you are at a stage where it is running, but not quite exactly as you expect. Like you, I suspect that it is a boundary condition that isn't exactly as you think it should be. I'd focus on that.
Let us know how it goes!

I found my BC issue. I forgot to change them back from the samller uniform mesh. Now it is like suspected.
Thank you so much for your support. You really helped me out :)
Also just noticed that you don't specify fluid_component = 1 for every kernel for the gp variable which you should do!

node.title: UK MOOSE Conference
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
The Centre For Modelling & Simulation (CFMS) is planning to host a UK MOOSE conference in February 2025 at our offices in Bristol, UK. CFMS have been utilising MOOSE in a number of projects beyond the nuclear sector and want to bring together experts from academia, RTOs and industry to foster the UK MOOSE community. The idea is to have a combination of talks from across the user base, highlighting the industrial challenges faced and the capabilities of MOOSE, hopefully prompting discussions as to how MOOSE can be applied.
We are starting to put an agenda together for this event and gauging interest from the community. It would be really helpful to know if this is something you would be interested in attending or have any suggestions. Please feel free to reply to this or contact me directly.
Thanks in advance.
Update January 2025
The registration page is now live, date is the 27th February. Link to the registration page:
https://cfms.org.uk/article/2025-uk-moose-conference-register-your-interest/
